ROADS BUILT BY KAMPONG DWELLERS


    2. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for National Development in how many kampongs were roads built by kampong dwellers with materials supplied by Government from 1st June, 1959, to the latest convenient date.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: There are two kampongs where assistance is being given by the Government and the people living in those kampongs have volunteered to build the roads themselves. They are Kampong Kubor and Kampong Farrer. Work is still in progress in both kampongs.

HOSTEL FOR MEMBERS OF LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY



    3. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Finance whether the hostel for Members of the Assembly is running at a profit or loss to Government.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr Low Por Tuck) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked to reply to this question.

    The hostel for Assemblymen is neither making a profit nor incurring a loss. The Assemblymen utilising the hostel pay a rent of $120 per month, which is the standard rent payable when the house is let furnished to Government officers. The occupants meet the recurrent cost for water and light. A telephone is provided at Government expense at $42 per quarter. No crockery or other amenities are provided.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Would the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance please say how many Assemblymen are occupying this hostel?

    Mr Low Por Tuck: If the Member for Cairnhill is so interested, I must have further notice of the question.

TEACHERS ON SICK LEAVE


    5. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Education how many teachers in Primary and Secondary English schools went on sick leave (a) between 1st September, 1958, and 30th June, 1959 (except when there was an epidemic), and (b) between .1st September, 1959, and 30th June, 1960 (except when there was an epidemic): and whether any instructions were given to the Medical Officer to keep medical leave down to a minimum.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: The number of teachers in primary and secondary English schools who went on sick leave for the ten-month period September 1958 to June 1959 was 2,528.

    I regret that it is not possible at such short notice to supply figures of teachers on sick leave for the ten-month period September 1959 to June 1960. The Member for Mountbatten, who until last year was the principal of a Government English primary school, should be aware that leave registers for Government schools for the year 1960 are not normally submitted to the Ministry till January 1961. I will, however, answer part of her question now, that is, for the four-month period September to December 1959. The number of teachers in Government and Government-aided English schools who applied for sick leave during this period was 1,561. The number of teachers from aided English schools who applied for sick leave during the six-month period January to June 1960 was 267, but the figures for the same period in respect of Government English school teachers will take some time, as explained just now, but will be supplied to the Member for Mountbatten when available.

    I am not aware of any specific instructions being issued to the Medical Officer to keep medical leave down to a minimum. It is normal practice to give medical leave only when the Medical Officer is satisfied that the condition of the officer justifies it.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the figures quoted were for the ten-month period September .1958 to June 1959 when the last Government was in office, and there are no comparative figures just yet for the period September 1959 to June 1960. I have only been able to supply part figures and, as already explained, the Member for Mountbatten, who was the principal of an English Government primary school, should know her General Orders and regulations - that the leave registers for Government schools do not come up to the Ministry till the end of the year.

(Number of resignations)

            and Government-aided schools            160

    Twelve of the 13 who resigned from the T.T.C. were expatriates of whom five opted to retire under Malayanisation terms and seven were married women on a temporary month-to-month basis.

    To judge the staffing position in schools purely on the figures of those who resigned will not provide a fair picture of the situation. Just as nature abhors a vacuum, so do vacancies arising not only from resignations but also from retirement or death be filled by recruitment. Therefore, to appreciate the staffing position in schools in its proper perspective, it is necessary to have an overall picture regarding the number of teachers as against the student enrolment, that is, the staff/student ratio.

    In June 1959, there were 9,870 teachers in Government and Government-aided schools, and the student enrolment was 308,333, or a staff/student ratio of 1 to 31. In June 1960, there were 10,428 teachers to 340,521 students, or a ratio of 1 to 33. During the year from June 1959 to May 1960, therefore, there has been an overall increase of 558 teachers and 32,188 students. This staff/student ratio of 1 to 33 is still exceedingly favourable when we bear in mind the fact that because of the heavy cost of education on the national budget we are now requiring classes to increase their capacity from the previous 40 to 44, or a staff/student ratio of 1 to 44.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, could the Minister inform this House as to the reasons why such a large number of teachers have resigned from Government service?

Column: 123



    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, men and women have varying reactions to responsibilities. Quite a number probably have resigned because the task of nation-building proves to be too heavy. Others think that teaching is a part-time business and could be indulged, while others think that it is time they went back to the Federation, or Sarawak, or Australia. It is difficult to give a general answer to a very sweeping question.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, the next question will not be so sweeping. The Minister has said that there is an increase in the number of teachers in the Education Department. Is it not a fact that that increase is the result of recruiting untrained teachers and teachers who are at present receiving training?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: The answer to the Member for Cairnhill is as follows. In June 1959, the T.T.C. had an enrolment of 2,241. In June 1960, the enrolment is 2,407, i.e. an increase of, shall we say, 160 only.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, the increase in enrolment of teachers in the T.T.C. does not reflect the increase in the number of teachers who are at present teaching, and who surely have to take a number of years before they can come out of the T.T.C. as qualified teachers.

    Mr Speaker: A supplementary question?

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: The supplementary question is: is it not a fact that the increase in the enrolment of teachers in the T.T.C. does not correctly reflect the increase in the number of teachers, as given by the Minister for Education?

    Mr Speaker: Would the Minister like to answer that question?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, in school we teach children that "one and two are three" and subtracting "one from three leaves two". I have given facts and figures which would appear not to click with the Member for Cairnhill, who is the former Minister for Education.

YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA'S SPEECH

(Debate on the Address)
(Second Day)


    Order read for resumption of adjourned debate on Question [3rd August, 1960],

    `That the following Address in reply to the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara be agreed to:-

    "We, the Legislative Assembly of the State of Singapore, express our thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for the speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the present session of this Assembly."'.-(The Prime Minister).

    Question again proposed.

2.52 p.m.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan (Hong Lim): Mr Speaker, the Prime Minister's speech yesterday was intended to confuse the real issues facing the people. After the Hong Lim Branch of the P.A.P. had tabled its historic 16 resolutions at the P.A.P. Special Party Conference called on 18th and 19th June, the Prime Minister used all the State and private organs of propaganda at his command - the State organs are like Radio Singapore and the private organs are all his agents, together with a rigid control of the Press - to systematically divert the attention of the people from the real issues by disseminating smears and distortions, by calling names as what he did yesterday, by concocting charges and smearing my work in the City Council and the Ministry of National Development. The offensive propaganda was carried out on a grand scale, which the Lim Yew Hock government had not learned. But it

Column: 125

was all the same - ineffective. Why was it ineffective? It is because of two basic reasons.. Firstly, the people have known for some time of the deviation of P.A.P. aims and policies by the Prime Minister and his able lieutenant, the Minister for Finance, who are the two persons responsible for steering the P.A.P. along its present actively pro-colonial course. Secondly, the Prime Minister is as good a propagandist as Dr Goebbels of the last war was. He tells the intellectuals one story. He tells the farmers, hawkers, workers, petty traders, and so on, another story. He tells the businessmen a third different story, and he goes on ad infinitum.

    To give an example, Mr Speaker - the so-called Minutes of the Party Conference were given to the Press in two different and distinct versions, one for the English-speaking members of the public and the other for the Chinese-speaking members of the public. But what happened? People meet at one time or another; the hawker could meet the clerk, the businessman could meet his employee, and the others, the bilingual and trilingual speaking public who could read both the Chinese and the English Press, when they compare the reports they find that they have been receiving different stories, in other words, different propaganda. Thus the people realise that it is mere propaganda, like Dr Goebbels' propaganda, and not the truth.

    The truth, Mr Speaker, is this. At the Badminton Hall rally, round about 30,000 people attended, half inside and half outside. Is it necessary for me, Mr Speaker, to convince you with photographs taken at the Hall? We can pass them around later if Mr Speaker will allow.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the hon. Member is giving me a very difficult task, and that is to draw a line somewhere. I do not think this Assembly is concerned with the internal strife of the Party itself. What, I think, the Assembly is concerned with is the overall picture which that strife perhaps has

Column: 126

created in Singapore. Therefore, I ask the hon. Member not to go into too many details, like producing photographs and things like that. Perhaps if the hon. Member will bear that in mind, we could then get back to the motion which is before the House.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Thank you, Mr Speaker. All my remarks are related to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech and to the Prime Minister's address. Though I have to make the necessary clarification, I will not produce the photographs any more.

    After the rally at the Badminton Hall, the Prime Minister was convinced that he had failed to divert the attention of the public from the Hong Lim resolutions, despite his intensive propaganda campaign and rigid suppression of the Press and mass rallies. The Ong Eng Guan scapegoat is not good enough; too small fry.

    In the past week, there has been little talk about Ong Eng Guan being anti-"collective leadership". No more. "Dr Goebbels'" first shot has failed. This is because we have effectively exploded the so-called "collective leadership" of the P.A.P. Nobody in Singapore believes it anymore. So, yesterday we heard in this Assembly of a new scapegoat, the so-called Left-wing adventurers. The first scapegoat - Ong Eng Guan. The second scapegoat - the Left-wing adventurers. And the third scapegoat, most probably, will be the Minister for Labour and Law.

    The people who turned up at the Badminton Hall rally were, by implication, the work of Left-wing adventurers, and not because the masses supported the Hong Lim resolutions. Mr Speaker, how would you explain the masses gathering at P.A.P. election rallies held before the P.A.P. formed the Government? Two Wednesdays ago, at the opening of this Assembly, there was the necessity to direct six lorry loads of Work Brigade members to stand in front of the Supreme Court to cheer and shout "Merdeka". As I said yesterday, you can lead a horse to the water, but you cannot force it to drink. The Brigade workers on that morning did not shout "Merdeka". I repeat, Sir, how would you explain the

Column: 127

masses gathering at P.A.P. election rallies before the P.A.P. formed the Government? Was that the work of Left-wing adventurers? You cannot effectively explain away the masses who turned up at the Badminton Hall. They turned up because they supported the Hong Lim resolutions which were concrete expressions of their hopes and grievances. They turned up because they had bottled up in their hearts for the past one year the bitter disappointment of the Government which they had voted in and to which they gave such an overwhelming majority, and which now betrayed their fundamental interests.

    It is not true when the Prime Minister said yesterday that "there was an absence of deep and abiding grievance among the people." Mr Speaker, how would he know? How would the Prime Minister know when he does not see the people but shuts himself up in the City Hall?

    The fight in Singapore today is still between the colonialists and the pro-colonialists on the one side and the people on the other side. The Prime Minister did his level best in his speech to convince us that his Government is still a progressive Government. His tactics are simple. After 14 months of strange silence, the Prime Minister started admonishing the K.M.T., the colonialists, the European interests, the colonialist newspapers. These are very simple kindergarten exercises. I hope this time the Speaker will not refuse me to practise a simple kindergarten exercise. I remember when I was in school I used to play this type of exercise. On one finger is a piece of paper. "Mr Speaker, see, this is right." But immediately I put this finger down, and I put another finger up, and the paper becomes left. So we are doing the same thing here.

    The Prime Minister admonished the K.M.T. and so on. He detained two journalists in the name of K.M.T. right-wing subversion,and he thus hoped the people will consider him left. And then the Prime Minister went on further to say:

    "The policy of the Communist Party... is to unite with all progressive forces, of which the P.A.P. is acknowledged as one, to

Column: 128

struggle against the forces of reaction, viz. colonialism, imperialism and feudalism."

And he said again:

    "We are not unaware that with the Communist on one side of us and the British colonialist on the other, each side will want to pull us to its side."

    Now, Mr Speaker, are these simple kindergarten exercises convincing? They would be as convincing as when the former Chief Minister, Mr Lim Yew Hock, said in this Assembly, "Gentlemen, I am anti-colonialist." Were the two journalists detained for K.M.T. sub version? Were they leaders of the so-called K.M.T. subversive organisation in Singapore? What I know is that one of them was detained 15 minutes after my Press conference on Sunday, 3rd July, 1960, on his way to his office near Cable and Wireless at Robinson Road to cable my Press releases to his paper in Kuala Lumpur. I do not support this paper because it always writes sensational articles. But what happened is this. Being a paper printed in Kuala Lumpur, its editors could not be called up and be intimidated, as editors of Singapore newspapers have been regularly intimidated, Mr Speaker. Sometimes this intimidation goes on for hours. This paper in Kuala Lumpur exploited the rigid control on Singapore's newspapers, arid its sale were boosted up from several hundred copies to many thousands of copies. So the best way was to detain these two journalists and teach the Singapore journalists a lesson. The Chinese proverb says: "Kill the cockerel in order to teach the monkey."

    How about the colonial newspapers which the Prime Minister mentioned yesterday? What the Prime Minister attacked was not the Straits Times. The British editorial writers of the Straits Times are good, of course. They wrote two editorial articles dated the 22nd of June and the 24th of June praising the stand of the Lee Kuan Yew Government. Why did the Prime Minister not mention about the Voice of America which was praising him? The person the Prime Minister attacked in his speech yesterday, by implication, was a local writer named Mr Huang Tze-chin, alias Francis Huang, who wrote a series of articles in the Sunday Mail about the

Column: 129

present political crisis. Our present Minister for Culture also used to write similarly. There is nothing wrong about it. Francis Huang is one who believes in liberal capitalism, if I can sum it up in two words, and if that is a correct description. After his first article in the Sunday Mail on the first Sunday after the Party conference, I believe he was called up and grilled for four solid hours. His second article negated his first article. I hope, gentlemen, to refresh your memory. And being not happy about it, Mr Huang wrote a third article which negated his second article. So the first article was his article; the second article was the Government's article; and the third article was his artic1e to negate his second article. He negated his second article by writing a third article and indirectly telling the people that he had written his second article under Government pressure. So we have these articles of Mr Francis Huang which are his own - the first article, the fourth article and the fifth article. What had Mr Huang Tze-chin written about which the Prime Minister said had confused and deluded the public? Mr Huang Tze-chin considered himself a political scientist, and advised the present ruling clique of the P.A.P. to come out in open support of liberalism and capitalism. He was not happy that now they were only supporting it in the dark. At the moment, it is actually a game of hide-and-seek. Mr Huang Tze-chin advised a national coalition.

    Mr Speaker, you will remember that in the days of the Lim Yew Hock Government, there had always been shouts of a national coalition, and the Singapore People's Alliance was thus formed. Mr Huang Tze-chin said:

    "The way can be prepared for a national coalition only if the suspicions left over by history are dispelled through a genuine revival of the bourgeois freedoms and the creation of an atmosphere of genuine liberalism."

Suspicions - about whom? About Lim Yew Hock? No mention is being made of a coalition with whom. Does it imply a national coalition with Lim Yew Hock?

Column: 130



    Mr Speaker: Order. The hon. Member has been mentioning the name of Lim Yew Hock very often. When he says "the Lim Yew Hock Government", perhaps it is excusable. But when he says, "Lim Yew Hock", I think he ought to say the Member for Cairnhill.

    An hon. Member: He is a popular man!

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, I think I should explain what I meant when I said "Lim Yew Hock". It is not so much the Member for Cairnhill himself, but the political force that he represents in Singapore. I am not referring to the present Member for Cairnhill as he is himself.

    Mr Huang Tze-chin then continued in the Sunday Mail. He gave these alternatives. He said:

    "What are the alternatives to the liberal analysis?

    One is to allow things to drift towards a smash-up in 1964.

    Another is to launch a wave of repression to mop up Ong and all who are not against him."

There will be many, many hundreds of thousands who are not against him.

    "A third is to intensify the present crisis into a constitutional crisis, thus inviting British intervention.

    A fourth is to give it all up as a bad job.

    None of these alternatives bear thinking about, if one shifts one's gaze from the tiny cockpit of Hong Lim to the decisive arena of the 1964 general election." Mr Huang Tze-chin concluded his article dated 17th July, 1960, with an attack on the Government's detention of the two journalists. And what did the Prime Minister think about this? He said this in his speech yesterday:

    "All this talk of absolute democratic rights, laissez-faire liberalism, freedom and human rights, in the face of the stark realities of an underground struggle for power, can only confuse the English-educated world."

In other words, he believes also in guided democracy. In other words, he also believes in sending riot squad vans to P.A.P. branch meetings, intimidation of Party members by sending C.I.D. men to see them in the dead of night, calling

Column: 131

them up and subjecting them to secret trials and so on, which the people have seen in plenty in the past six weeks.

    Mr Speaker, by implication, the Prime Minister, in his reference to Huang Tze-chin's articles, although he does not mention those articles by name, wants the European imperialists, colonialists, the bosses of the Straits Times who control the Sunday Mail, to clamp down on writers like Huang Tze-chin. It was the same when the Lim Yew Hock Government wanted the Straits Times to clamp down on writers like Mr S. Rajaratnam, who is at present the Minister for Culture. Mr Speaker, the Prime Minister does not want to clamp down on British editorial writers who praise the present Government.

    Again, the Prime Minister in his speech yesterday talked about the Communist Party on the one side and the colonialists on the other. So a very simple exercise again, trying to imply that the Government are in the centre and they are not therefore pro-colonialists. How would the Prime Minister explain then the presence of expatriates like Thomson, Blades and Meadows in control of key positions in the machinery of the State? So these expatriates are not colonialists at all. And again he implied:

    "People say the P.A.P. is progressive, so I, the Prime Minister, must also be progressive."

The members of the P.A.P. are progressive. The P.A.P. Assemblymen and even some of the Ministers are still reasonable. The Deputy Prime Minister, the Minister for Home Affairs and our Minister for Culture are reasonable and nice gentlemen. But it is these two persons, the Prime Minister and his able lieutenant, the Minister for Finance, who have in the past year steered the present Government along a pro-colonial course. The Prime Minister said yesterday - this one is important-yesterday was 3rd August, 1960:

    "The British want to preserve their economic and military interests ... for as long as possible."

May I repeat it again?

    "The British want to preserve their economic and military interests...for as long as possible."

Column: 132



    "Economic and military interests" are, like in a magic show, switched back again after our exposure at the Badminton Hall rally on the 12th July, 1960. A year ago, on the 17th July, 1959, after the Government was formed, the Prime Minister wrote these words in the Petir editorial:
